title: 2021 California gubernatorial recall election
added: The recall election results will be officially certified by October 22, 2021.<ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/after-newsom-s-victory-california-democrats-seek-changes-recall-process-n1279281</ref>

title: 2021 California gubernatorial recall election
added: The recall election results will be officially certified by October 22, 2021.<ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/after-newsom-s-victory-california-democrats-seek-changes-recall-process-n1279281</ref>

title: 2021 California gubernatorial recall election
deleted: Larry Elder's association with and support for the [[Trump Administration]], as well as his status as a front-runner in the race, were reported to have likely helped Newsom defeat the recall.<ref name="blah1"/><ref name="blah2"/> Mid-summer polling (conducted two months prior to election day) suggested a close race.<ref name="blah1"/><ref name="blah2"/> Newsom ultimately defeated the recall with a margin of roughly 24 percent following his campaigning that invoked Elder's connections to former [[President Donald Trump]] and his inner circle<ref name="blah1">{{cite web|url=https://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article253647713.html|title=Larry Elder is leader among California recall candidates. That might help Gavin Newsom|website=The Sacremento Bee|date=August 23, 2021|last1=Bollag|first1=Sophia}}</ref><ref name="blah2">{{cite web|last=Reston |first=Maeve |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/14/politics/larry-elder-covid-newsom-recall/index.html |title=How Larry Elder has helped Gavin Newsom in California's recall election - CNNPolitics |publisher=Cnn.com |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2021}}</ref> as well as his history of provocative right-wing rhetoric as a radio talk show host.<ref>https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-09-13/skelton-recall-newsom-elder-poll?_amp=true</ref>

title: 2021 California gubernatorial recall election
added: On July 24, 2021, the California Republican Party's steering committee voted to allow the party to endorse a candidate in the recall election, if the candidate received at least 60 percent of delegate votes in an upcoming August 7 meeting. Some Republicans opposed the move out of concern that endorsing a single candidate would reduce Republican voter turnout.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/07/24/california-republican-party-creates-recall-endorsement-path-1388974/|title=California Republican Party creates recall endorsement path|first=Jeremy B.|last=White|date=July 24, 2021|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref> On August 7, the party voted to cancel the endorsement vote and issue no endorsement;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/08/07/california-gop-wont-endorse-a-candidate-in-newsom-recall-1389718/|title=California GOP won't endorse a candidate in Newsom recall|first=Jeremy B.|last=White|date=August 7, 2021|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref> prior to the cancellation of the endorsement vote, Republican delegates were set to choose an endorsee from the four candidates who each had received the support of at least 200 delegates, which were [[Larry Elder]], [[Kevin Faulconer]], [[Kevin Kiley (politician)|Kevin Kiley]], and [[Doug Ose]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2021-08-07/cagop-endorsement-vote-jenner-elder-faulconer-ose-kiley?_amp=true|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=State GOP votes not to endorse a candidate in the recall race|first=Seema|last=Mehta|date=August 7, 2021}}</ref>
